title: 2. From Physical to Functional
introduction_html: A core innovation of IPWT is liberating the concept of 'integration' from the rigid constraints of physics, as proposed by Integrated Information Theory (IIT), and redefining it as a functional property of information processing.
content_html:
Original IIT's Bottleneck

  • Physical Substrate Dependency: Consciousness is tied to the 'intrinsic causal structure' of a specific physical system.
  • Computational Infeasibility: Calculating Phi (Φ) is an NP-Hard problem, making it practically impossible for complex systems.
  • Static View: Focuses on the causal structure at a single moment, struggling to explain the dynamic nature of consciousness.

IPWT's Functional Solution

  • Logical Irreducibility: Integration is defined by synergistic information—a property of information flow, not physical atoms.
  • Computable Proxy (PI): Instead of calculating Ω directly, we measure its functional consequence: Predictive Integrity (PI).
  • Dynamic Process: By embedding integration within the Predictive Coding framework, IPWT treats consciousness as a continuous process.

Integration is not a property of atoms, but of informational synergy.

title: 3. The Math of Synergy: PID & ΦID
introduction_html: IPWT's concept of 'logical irreducibility' is grounded in information theory, specifically Partial Information Decomposition (PID) and its extension, Integrated Information Decomposition (ΦID).
content_html:
These frameworks decompose the information that multiple sources (X₁, X₂) provide about a target (Y) into distinct atoms:

  • Redundancy: Information available from either X₁ or X₂ alone.
  • Unique Information: Information that can only be gained from X₁ or only from X₂.
  • Synergy (Ω): The crucial part. This is 'emergent' information that is only available when considering X₁ and X₂ together.

While ΦID provides a more complete picture, its complexity is immense. Therefore, IPWT uses Synergy as its theoretical bedrock but relies on the practical, computable proxy of Predictive Integrity (PI) for empirical testing.

Synergy (Ω) is the theoretical basis of integration; Predictive Integrity (PI) is its empirical proxy.

title: 4. Predictive Integrity (PI) Explained
introduction_html: PI is a functional metric designed to quantify the effectiveness and stability of a conscious state. It's derived from the Free Energy Principle, reflecting the trade-off between accuracy and complexity.
content_html:
PI_t = exp(-α * (Inaccuracy + γ * Complexity))

  • Inaccuracy: The precision-weighted prediction error (ε). The cost of being wrong.
  • Complexity: The 'cost' of updating the internal model. A simple, elegant model is preferred (Occam's Razor).
  • γ (Gamma): A hyperparameter that balances the trade-off between accuracy and complexity.

A high PI score signifies a system that is both accurate in its predictions and efficient in its model structure—hallmarks of a robust, integrated, and conscious state.

Consciousness as a state of optimized trade-offs between predictive accuracy and model complexity.

title: 5. Case Study: Blindsight
introduction_html: Patients with V1 cortex damage report being blind, yet can 'guess' the location of objects at above-chance levels. IPWT provides a clear computational explanation.
content_html:
• ➤
    Dominant WSI Fails: The main workspace for subjective visual experience receives no high-quality input from the damaged V1. Its contribution to the DWSI's synergistic information (Ω) is near zero, hence no subjective 'seeing'.
  • ➤
    Local Modules Succeed: Visual information still reaches other, specialized modules via subcortical pathways. These local modules can run their own, unconscious predictive coding cycles and directly guide behavior.

Blindsight demonstrates the critical distinction between mere information processing and the global, synergistic integration within a dominant workspace that is necessary for subjective awareness.

Processing without synergistic integration is not awareness.

title: 6. Case Study: Schizophrenia
introduction_html: The diverse symptoms of schizophrenia can be unified under a single umbrella: a fundamental dysregulation of the predictive coding machinery.
content_html:
• Aberrant Salience: The brain incorrectly assigns high precision (importance) to random prediction errors, leading to delusions.
  • Failure of Self-Monitoring: Hallucinations can be seen as the failure to predict and cancel out one's own inner speech. The resulting unpredicted sensory signal is misinterpreted as external.
  • WSI Gating Failure: Thought disorder may arise from the WSI's inability to properly gate information, allowing irrelevant thoughts to intrude into the conscious workspace.

This computational psychiatry approach allows us to see schizophrenia not as a collection of strange behaviors, but as a predictable consequence of a malfunctioning Bayesian inference engine.

Psychopathology as a failure mode of the brain's Bayesian inference engine.

title: 7. The 'Hard Problem' as a Functional Question
introduction_html: IPWT tackles the 'hard problem' of qualia (subjective experience) not by asking 'what is the feeling of red?', but by asking 'what is the function of the feeling of red?'.
content_html:
Qualia as High-Level Functional Labels

A quale is a highly compressed, behaviorally-relevant summary of a complex state, broadcast through the workspace to compel action.

The 'sharpness' of pain is a functional label for a state of bodily harm that requires immediate withdrawal. They are evolution's solution to information overload, turning complex data into simple, undeniable action commands.

This reframing turns an intractable philosophical mystery into a tractable scientific problem about information compression, salience, and behavioral control.

Qualia are not mystical properties, but high-bandwidth, compressed data labels for behavioral control.
